subject: Re: [junit] How to test private member variables?
msgSnippet: ... Presumably you have a design like this: MyClass MyClass(arg1, arg2, arg3, ...) { this.arg1 = arg1; ... } main(String[] args) { arg1 = parse(args[0]); ...
messageBody:
>So said jxingtang on 2003-07-23 --------------------
>I have a program to setup quite a few private member variables during
>initialization. Particular, it extracts command line arguments passed
>to the main method. How do I verify that command line arguments are
>extracted corrctly to the right private member variables? Do I have
>to add a bunch of new public get methods for those variables? I do
>not like this idea as the design is affected by testing. Could
>someone provide some better approaches? Thanks in advance!

Presumably you have a design like this:

MyClass
MyClass(arg1, arg2, arg3, ...) {
this.arg1 = arg1;
...
}

main(String[] args) {
arg1 = parse(args[0]);
...

new MyClass(arg1, arg2, ...).go();
}

Now what do you want to test?

1. That main() parses the command line arguments correctly?

In this case, build parsing into a separate class and test it. Perhaps the argument parser answers a Map of name -> argument value. In this case, it's easy to verify that the parser answers the expected Map.

Once you've done this, main() calls the parser, then does stuff like this:

new MyClass(
(Integer) args.get("blah"),
(String) args.get("foo"),
...
);

A little ugly, due to the casting, but not horrible.

2. That main() passes the parameters correctly to MyClass' constructor?

Rather than expose getX() methods, add equals() that compares two MyClass objects and answers true if their fields have the same values. Then in your test, set up the "expected MyClass" with the argument values you expect main() to pass in and use assertEquals() to compare them.

Take care.
